Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Central Anatolian Tectonics (CD-CAT): Surface to mantle dynamics during collision to escape
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves an integrated program to study the process of tectonic escape in Central Anatolia. This is the location where this process was first recognized in the 1970s and the PIs make a strong case that this is good place to investigate the temporal and spatial characteristics of this process in the context of a continent-continent collision.

The research builds on previous geophysical and geological studies by many of the PIs in other parts of Turkey (both to the east and west of the planned study area). The research will investigate modern structure through a combination of geophysics and geology. Past history will be reconstructed through studies of elevation, drainage and volcanism. Studies of the Central Anatolian fault are important as this is a major feature that is poorly understood in Anatolian tectonics.

Specifically, the PIs will address the questions:

? What are the plate dynamics from the mantle to the Earth?s surface, the transition from distributed to localized strain in large strike-slip faults, the origin and consequences of magmatism, and the evolution of relief and landscape during development of escape tectonics?
? What are the effects of boundary conditions (collision of Arabian plate to the east, extension of Aegean to the west, subduction of African plate to the south) on the driving forces of tectonic escape?

The study will integrate results of passive seismic experiments; magnetotelluric profiling; geomorphic, structural, and stratigraphic-sedimentological analysis of surface geology and exhumed orogenic crust; geo/thermochronometric determination of temperature-time histories of magmatic, metamorphic, and fault zone rocks and geomorphic features; isotopic fingerprinting and dating of magmatic rocks; and 2D and 3D numerical modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We collected approximately 1 Terrabyte of continuously recorded seismic data over approximately 24 months. These data were very important better understanding the early stages of mountaing building related to oceanic subduction. 

As a part of the work we located earthquakes across central Turkey. We found clustering of earthquakes along the East Anatolian Fault, as expected; however, the Central Anatolian Fault Zone, generally considered to be less seismically active, also shows a significant amount of seismic activity that is suggestive of internal deformation within the Anatolian plate. Additional seismicity is observed along the North Anatolian Fault and near volcanically active regions of central Anatolia. These local earthquake hypocenters will help constrain crustal deformation patterns as well as crustal scale magma bodies that are associated with the volcanic activity in central Anatolia. Accurate hypocenters are crucial for further seismic analyses including local shear wave splitting, seismic attenuation, and focal mechanism studies. Furthermore, this work could have implications for populated regions of central Turkey near active fault zones at the plate interior where seismicity is not well understood.

We have found small regions of very low S-wave and P-wave velocities located in the middle crust (10-20km) in the vicinity of the Holocene volcanism.  We have determined these are likely the result of mid crustal melting.

We have also found regions of high crustal Q values and low Lg attenuation across the Central Anatolian Fault Zone (CAFZ).  These observatoins may suggest that this region is tectonically stable crust relative to other parts of Central Anatolia .  We also find very low Q values in the vicinity of the Central Anatolian Holocene volcanism. This high crustal attenuation may be caused by crustal thinning in this region possibly due to major lithospheric extension. Alternatively, the low QLg values could be a resutl of partial melt within the crust.  Preliminary estimates of the frequency dependence of the Lg Q values would suggest that much of the attenuation is caused by the melt.

As a part of this project we have also studied uppermost mantle seismic attenuation as well in order to better understand the source of seismic anomalies in this seismically active region.  We find a strong correlation between shear wave attenuation and shear wave velocity for the uppermost mantle.


Last Modified: 03/02/2020
Modified by: Eric Sandvol

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: We collected approximately 1 Terrabyte of continuously recorded seismic data over approximately 24 months. These data were very important better understanding the early stages of mountaing building related to oceanic subduction. As a part of the work we located earthquakes across central Turkey. We found clustering of earthquakes along the East Anatolian Fault, as expected; however, the Central Anatolian Fault Zone, generally considered to be less seismically active, also shows a significant amount of seismic activity that is suggestive of internal deformation within the Anatolian plate. Additional seismicity is observed along the North Anatolian Fault and near volcanically active regions of central Anatolia. These local earthquake hypocenters will help constrain crustal deformation patterns as well as crustal scale magma bodies that are associated with the volcanic activity in central Anatolia. Accurate hypocenters are crucial for further seismic analyses including local shear wave splitting, seismic attenuation, and focal mechanism studies. Furthermore, this work could have implications for populated regions of central Turkey near active fault zones at the plate interior where seismicity is not well understood. We have found small regions of very low S-wave and P-wave velocities located in the middle crust (10-20km) in the vicinity of the Holocene volcanism. We have determined these are likely the result of mid crustal melting. We have also found regions of high crustal Q values and low Lg attenuation across the Central Anatolian Fault Zone (CAFZ). These observatoins may suggest that this region is tectonically stable crust relative to other parts of Central Anatolia . We also find very low Q values in the vicinity of the Central Anatolian Holocene volcanism. This high crustal attenuation may be caused by crustal thinning in this region possibly due to major lithospheric extension. Alternatively, the low QLg values could be a resutl of partial melt within the crust. Preliminary estimates of the frequency dependence of the Lg Q values would suggest that much of the attenuation is caused by the melt. As a part of this project we have also studied uppermost mantle seismic attenuation as well in order to better understand the source of seismic anomalies in this seismically active region.
